text: BR17120 Genetics, Evolution and Diversity: Living vertebrates & evolution of the gnathostomes. Jo Hamilton (e-mail: jvh) Objectives and learning outcomes.  Gnathostomes & evolution of jaws.  Chondrichthyes & Osteichthyes.  Intro to tetrapod origins. Gnathostomes are vertebrates that have jaws…  Jawless craniates survivors from Paleozoic era.  Gnathostomes far outnumber Agnatha.  Living gnathostomes – diverse – Sharks & relatives – Ray-finned fish & lobe-finned fish – Amphibians – Reptiles & birds – Mammals http://ths.sps.lane.edu/biomes/mari ne4/marine4.html https://www.pinterest.co.uk/pin/55717 9785119716674/ https://www.floridamuseum.ufl.edu/ev ent/world-sea-turtle-day/ http://www.okbirds.com/?cat=29http://artigoo com/leopardo-felino-agil Gnathostomes are vertebrates that have jaws…  Gnathostomes (“jaw-mouth”).  Advantages of jaws – hinged structures – Gripping & slicing food – esp. if teeth. – Active predation- capture/bite prey items – Manipulate food-improved digestion – Herbivory – Mouth brooding – Nest building/mate grasping etc. – Improved gill ventilation Gnathostomes are vertebrates that have jaws… Other derived gnathostome characteristics – Additional duplication Hox genes (4 clusters). – Other gene clusters duplicated  Genetic complexity - developmental complexity? – Enlarged forebrain cf other craniates - olfaction, vision. – Aquatic gnathostomes - lateral line system  Sensitive to vibrations  Early versions in head shields some jawless verts. Evolution of jaws from branchial arches … Hypothesis modification skeletal rods - supported ant. pharyngeal gill slits. Remaining gill slits – gas exchange. Fossil Gnathostomes …  Gnathostomes – emerged mid-Ordovician period ~ 470 MYA.  Diverse & successful – Paired fins & tail – efficient swimming – Jaws – grab prey & bite flesh – bite force  Placoderms earliest fossil gnathostomes – E.g. Dunkleosteus  – “plate skinned”- armoured – Most < 1m but some > 10m – Extinct early in Carboniferous. http://www.bio.miami.edu/dana/106/106F06_16p rint.html Zachi Evenor - Dunkleosteus, CC BY 3.0, https://commons.wikimedia.org/w/index.php?curid =36545364 Fossil Gnathostomes …  Acanthodians – radiated during Devonian era – many new forms - marine & freshwater habitats – probably sister group to the bony fish (Osteichthyes)  mouth opening mechanism-hyoid attachment  dermal (not plated) operculum, true dermal teeth  Extinct - end Devonian ~360 MYA Gyracanthus sp. http://www.devoniantimes.org/who /pages/gyracanthus.html Chondrichthyes are the sharks, rays & their relatives …  Chondrichthyes – “cartilage fish”.  Skeleton – cartilage – often impregnated with calcium  Cartilaginous skeleton not primitive condition – traces bone in living chondrichthyans – most likely secondarily derived.  Sharks, rays & skates (~1000 sp.) – Largest & most diverse group.  Second group – ~ 40 species chimeras (ratfish/rabbitfish). Chimera monstrosa http://www.guppies.za.net/rabbit-fish-chimaera-monstrosa-fish- profile.aspx Sharks…  Streamlined body – poor maneuverability  Forward propulsion - trunk & caudal fin  Dorsal fins – stablilisers  Paired pectoral & pelvic fins – lift  Bouyancy – oil - liver & continual swimming  Continual swimming – gas exchange  Problem when resting on seafloor – Use jaw & pharynx muscles to pump water over gills https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Carcharhinus_perezi_ ahamas2.jpg Sharks…  Largest sharks & rays - planktonic suspension feeders  Most sharks – carnivorous.  Several rows teeth – move ant. as old teeth lost.  Shorter digestive tract than many verts – spiral valve - intestine – corkscrew- shaped ridge – increases s.a. & slows digestive transit. Carcharodon carcharius (great white shark) Hyostylic jaw extension http://uk.youtube.com/watch ?v=x7fZyrcwrRs http://www.sharkwatchsa.com/en/ Sharks…  Sharp vision – not colours.  Olfaction – nostrils - dead-end cups.  Electrophysiology – detect electric fields - muscle contraction – other animals.  No eardrums – entire body transmits sound to inner ear. https://www.pinterest.co.uk/pin/556405728933379960/ Sharks…  Internal fertilisation – pelvic claspers - sperm. Various reproductive strategies  Oviparous – eggs in protective coat hatch outside body.  Ovoviviparous – fertilised egg retained in oviduct, nourished by yolk, offspring hatch in uterus.  Viviparous – offspring develop in uterus, nourished by yolk sac / absorbing uterine fluid / eating other eggs.  Cloaca – single opening to outside. http://www.jotform.us/f orm/42746892654165 Rays…  Rays - different lifestyle.  Most - bottom-dwellers.  Feed on molluscs & crustaceans.  Flattened shape - enlarged pectoral fins - propulsion.  Tail – whiplike & may bear venomous barbs.  Overfishing – major threat to chondrichthyes. http://www.youtube.com/ watch?v=ChzktBcXg1k http://www.youtube.com/ watch?v=YsnubgtLOCA https://www.google.co.uk/imgres?imgurl=http://www. sdnhm.org/oceanoasis/fieldguide/images/mantaray.jp g&imgrefurl=http://www.sdnhm.org/oceanoasis/fieldg uide/mant-bir.html&h=244&w=225&tbnid=- 5Xpq0guy32QbM&tbnh=234&tbnw=216&usg=__PySV glgD1JBxqMCtSpn5ktDoc08=&hl=en-GB&docid=jzM- FOB_scnhkM Osteichthyes include the bony fish and tetrapods …  Majority verts - clade gnathostomes called Osteichthyes.  Osteichthyes – “bony fish”  But … includes bony fish & tetrapods.  Almost all osteichthyes - ossified endoskeleton with hard matrix calcium phosphate. Osteichthyes – fish…  Operculum - protective bony flap covering gill chamber – Gill chamber - 4 or 5 pairs of gills.  Operculum movement & contraction muscles surrounding gill chamber draws water - through mouth - pharynx & out between gills. https://www.google.co.uk/imgres?imgurl=http://w ww.kepu.net.cn/english/goldfish/fantail%2520gold fish/200303040036_10237.jpg&imgrefurl=http://w ww.kepu.net.cn/english/goldfish/fantail%20goldfis h/200303040036.html&h=260&w=350&tbnid=8KV iFfgjkbr6KM&tbnh=193&tbnw=261&usg=__ucScV oL7nFZk39Jfa_wIBZFOOTw=&hl=en- GB&docid=5H9M0v-0hRLTCM Osteichthyes – fish…  Bouyancy – swim bladder – Movement gases from blood to swim bladder & v.v. control bouyancy.  Charles Darwin proposed tetrapod lungs evolved from swim bladders.  But …. appears lungs arose in early osteichthyes – swim bladders evolved from lungs some lineages. http://www.biology- online.org/articles/swim_bladder_ideas_anatomy.html Osteichthyes – fish…  Most fish covered in bony scales – different to tooth-like shark scales.  Glands secrete mucus onto skin – reduces drag.  Lateral line (row tiny pits) either side body.  Diverse reproductive strategies. http://www.laterallineco.com/fish_lateral_line.html Actinopterygii are the ray- finned fish …  ~32000 species.  Bony rays support fins – group name – Modified for maneuvering, defence, etc.  Originated in f.w. & spread to seas. – Many species returned to fresh water. – Some species - both fresh & seawater (e.g. salmon).  Human pressures - protein source, overfishing, environmental change. Sarcopterygii are the lobe-fins …  Sarcopterygii - evolved in Devonian – along with ray-finned fish. Key derived character  Pectoral & pelvic fins - rod-shaped bones surrounded by thick layer muscle.  Devonian Sarcopterygii – brackish waters – e.g. coastal wetlands – Used lobed fins to swim & “walk” underwater across substrate. Sarcopterygii are the lobe-fins …  Only 3 extant lineages – Coelacanths (Actinistia) – Lungfish (Dipnoi) – Tetrapods http://vertebrates.si.edu/fishes/coelacanth/coelacanth_wider.html www.aqualifestyle-france.com/t144-protopterus-annectens-annectens https://mrogers.wikispaces.com/Acanthostega Sarcopterygii are the lobe-fins … Coelacanths (Actinistia)  Thought extinct ~65 million years ago.  Caught - 1938 off Comoros Islands, western Indian Ocean.  Second population – 1999- eastern Indian Ocean near Indonesia  represent second species.  Secondarily derived cartilaginous skeleton. Sarcopterygii are the lobe-fins … Lungfish (Dipnoi)  6 species - 3 genera - Southern Hemisphere.  Evolved in ocean  Now only f.w. (stagnant ponds / swamps).  Surface - gulp air - lungs connected - pharynx.  Also gills – main organ for gas exchange in Australian lungfish.  Dry season – burrow mud & aestivate. www.aqualifestyle-france.com/t144-protopterus-annectens-annectens Tetrapods are gnathostomes that have limbs  One most significant events vert history ~ 360 MYA – fins lobe-fins evolved - limbs & feet tetrapods. – fish fins for “walking” – frogfish – http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=F8VyOuJ8Uak&featu re=related  Tetrapod – “four feet”.  Limbs in place of pectoral & pelvic fins – Support weight on land – Transmit muscle generated forces to ground. Summary  Gnathostomes & evolution of jaws.  Chondrichthyes & Osteichthyes.  Intro to tetrapod origins.
